metadata.title: Convert Gradians to Arcseconds - Angle Converter
metadata.description: Convert between gradians (also called grads or gon) and arcseconds with exact, standards-based factors and practical guidance for surveying, mapping, and laboratory use.

introduction: This converter translates angles measured in gradians (also called grads or gon) into arcseconds using an exact mathematical relationship. Gradians subdivide the right angle into 100 parts and the full circle into 400 gradians; arcseconds are the sexagesimal subdivision of degrees (1° = 60′ = 3600″).

The conversion here is exact and intended for professional contexts (surveying, geodesy, navigation, astronomy) where traceability and instrument resolution matter. Where applicable, verify results against instrument calibration certificates and follow national metrology guidelines for measurement uncertainty.
Use the simple input to convert a single value; consult the methodology and FAQs for the exact factor, recommended rounding, and notes on instrument limits and regulatory traceability.
methodology: Start from the fundamental relationships: 1 full circle = 400 gradians = 360 degrees, and 1 degree = 3600 arcseconds. Combine these to derive the exact factor between gradians and arcseconds.

Because the relationships above are exact by definition, the arithmetic conversion is exact: 1 gradian = (9/10) degree = 0.9° = 3240 arcseconds. For conversion use the integer factor 3240 or its reciprocal depending on direction.

When applying results in practice, choose rounding consistent with instrument resolution and the intended use: laboratory reporting should follow NIST/ISO traceability and report uncertainty; field work typically rounds to the nearest instrument least-count (see FAQs and citations).
examples: Example 2: 1,000 arcseconds → 1,000 ÷ 3240 ≈ 0.3086419753 gradians (round to required precision).

faqs.question: What is the exact conversion factor between gradians and arcseconds?
faqs.answer: Exactly 1 gradian = (9/10) degree and 1 degree = 3600 arcseconds, so 1 gradian = 0.9° = 0.9 × 3600 = 3240 arcseconds. The reciprocal is 1 arcsecond = 1/3240 gradian (≈ 0.00030864197530864197 gradian).

faqs.question: Is this conversion exact or approximate?
faqs.answer: The mathematical relationship is exact because it derives from the definitions of the units. Any approximation arises only from decimal rounding when displaying or reporting values.

faqs.question: How should I choose rounding or significant figures?
faqs.answer: Match rounding to the resolution of your measurement device and the uncertainty you can substantiate. For high-precision lab work, keep enough digits to encompass instrument uncertainty and report uncertainty per NIST/ISO guidance. For field surveying, round to the instrument least-count (for example, a device with 1 arcsecond resolution need not report fractional arcseconds).

faqs.question: What instrument limits or calibration steps should I consider?
faqs.answer: Verify the instrument's least-count and calibration certificate. Ensure angular sensors or theodolites have current calibration and that you document traceability to a national metrology institute when required. Follow manufacturer procedures for periodic calibration and use appropriate environmental controls to reduce systematic error.

faqs.question: Can I convert bearings or directions that cross the 0/360 (wrap-around) boundary?
faqs.answer: Yes. Convert the numeric angle value using the factor shown, then apply modular arithmetic as required for wrap-around (e.g., normalize to the desired range such as 0–400 gradians or 0–360 degrees) so directional semantics are preserved.

faqs.question: Which professional standards or references cover these units and traceability?
faqs.answer: Guidance on units, traceability, and reporting of measurement uncertainty is available from national metrology bodies and standards organizations. See NIST guidance and national geodetic services for traceability and reporting practices; refer to the citations below for authoritative resources.

faqs.question: What are common applications for converting gradians to arcseconds?
faqs.answer: Applications include surveying and civil engineering (where gradians are sometimes used for bearings), cartography, geodetic computations, and astronomy when mixing sexagesimal and decimal angular units. Always maintain consistent units across computations to avoid transcription errors.
